member.name: T:SolidShineUi.ArithmeticParser
member.summary: Contains functionality to parse and evaluate math arithmetic expressions.

member.name: M:SolidShineUi.ArithmeticParser.Evaluate(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluate an arithmetic expression and output the result (i.e. "2+5" will output "7"). See remarks for more info on supported functions.
member.param: The arithmetic expression to evaluate.
member.exception: Thrown if the expression is not valid (contains unrecognized characters or a mismatched number of parantheses).
member.returns: The result of the expression.
member.remarks:
Supports addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and exponents. Also supports parantheses (with implied multiplcation) and negative numbers.
Uses order of operations: exponents, division, multiplication, subtraction, addition.
Whitespace and new-line characters are removed prior to evaluation, and the literal characters ×, ⋅, and ÷ are replaced with their representations *, *, and /.

member.name: M:SolidShineUi.ArithmeticParser.IsValidString(System.String)
member.summary: Check if a string can be parsed as an expression.
member.param: The string to parse.
member.returns: True if it is a string that can be parsed. False if it contains invalid characters.

member.name: T:SolidShineUi.BindableHighContrast
member.summary: When set up properly, allows a WPF control style to be triggered when the Windows High Contrast mode setting is changed. See remarks for details.
member.remarks: For the control or style in question that you want to monitor changes to high contrast in, set the property flat:BindableHighContrast.HighContrast = "{DynamicResource ResourceKey={x:Static Member=SystemParameters.HighContrastKey}}" in the control or style. Then you can use the trigger as such: <Trigger Property="flat:BindableHighContrast.HighContrast" Value="True"> ... </Trigger>. Visit this StackOverflow question for more information and source. This class is identical to the "SystemParameterProperties" class in the accepted answer.

member.name: T:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage
member.summary: The image to use when displaying a message dialog.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.None
member.summary: No image is displayed. This may be good for generic messages, but is not recommended for situations where the user should pay attention to the message.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Error
member.summary: A white X on a red background is displayed. This is good for situations where an error or exception has occurred, or something isn't acting as intended.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Warning
member.summary: An exclamation point on a yellow triangle is displayed. This is good when informing the user about potential errors or unintended side effects.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Question
member.summary: A white question mark on a blue background is displayed. This is good when asking a question or when asking for confirmation for a routine task.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Hand
member.summary: A white exclamation point on a blue background is displayed. This is good for when wanting to alert the user about something that isn't considered a warning.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Info
member.summary: A white I on a blue background is displayed. This is good for generally informing the user about something, such as a task being completed or the response to a request.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Stop
member.summary: A red stop sign is displayed. This is good for informing the user that this action isn't valid in the current state, or that an unavoidable major issue has occurred.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImage.Lock
member.summary: A yellow lock is displayed. This is good for situations where security or authentication are involved.

member.name: T:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImageConverter
member.summary: A helper class that can retrieve a BitmapImage from a MessageDialogImage.

member.summary: Return a 32x32 image to use with a message dialog. If the MessageDialogImage argument is "None", then null is returned.
member.param: The image to display. If "None", then null is returned.
The color to use for the image. Use black or white for high-contrast themes.

member.name: T:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogImageConverter.MessageDialogImageColor
member.summary: The color to use with a message dialog image.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogButtonDisplay.Auto
member.summary: If set, uses the OkButtonText, CancelButtonText, and DiscardButtonText properties to determine which buttons should be displayed. If a property is null, then the corresponding button isn't displayed.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogButtonDisplay.One
member.summary: Display only one button, the OK button. Outputs as MessageDialogResult.OK when clicked.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogButtonDisplay.Two
member.summary: Display two buttons, the OK and Cancel buttons. Outputs as MessageDialogResult.OK or MessageDialogResult.Cancel when clicked.

member.name: F:SolidShineUi.MessageDialogButtonDisplay.Three
member.summary: Display three buttons, the OK, Discard, and Cancel buttons. Outputs as MessageDialogResult.OK, MessageDialogResult.Discard or MessageDialogResult.Cancel when clicked.

member.summary: Get the result of the dialog when it is closed. "False" refers to the user cancelling the operation, while "True" refers to the user confirming, by clicking "OK" or pressing the Enter key.

member.name: P:SolidShineUi.StringInputDialog.EnterKeyConfirms
member.summary: Get or set whether the Enter key can be used to confirm the dialog. If enabled, pressing down the Enter key will be treated as if the user pressed "OK".

member.name: P:SolidShineUi.StringInputDialog.EscapeKeyCancels
member.summary: Get or set whether the Escape key can be used to cancel the dialog. If enabled, pressing down the Escape key will be treated as if the user pressed "Cancel".

member.summary: Get or set whether all of the text in the text box should be selected when the text box receives focus.

member.name: P:SolidShineUi.StringInputDialog.Description
member.summary: Get or set the description text to display above the text box. This text should describe what the user should enter into the text box.
member.remarks: Try to keep the description to about a sentence long. Ideally, the overall design of the program should make it apparent what the user should enter into the text box without reading the description.

member.summary: Get or set if the top-left element should be considered part of the window chrome or not. Set to true to exclude it from the window chrome.

member.summary: This event is raised when the control is clicked.

member.summary: Get or set the standard foreground brush for the text. This overwrites the Foreground property.

member.summary: Get or set the brush for when the control has mouseover or keyboard focus.

member.summary: Get or set the brush for when the control is disabled.

member.name: P:SolidShineUi.LinkTextBlock.AutoSetLinkFromText
member.summary: Get or set if the LinkTextBlock should automatically create a link based upon the Text property. See remarks for more details.
member.remarks:
When AutoSetLinkFromText is set to true, the LinkTextBlock attempts to open a file or URL based upon the value of the Text property when the user clicks on the control. For example, if this property is set to true and the Text property is set to "https://microsoft.com", the LinkTextBlock will open "https://microsoft.com" when the control is clicked, even if a Click event handler is not attached. Note that for web links, the scheme/protocol should be present (i.e. "http", "https", "ftp", etc.).
Note that the Click event will still fire even if this property is set to true.
If an error occurs while attempting to open the link, nothing happens. If a debugger is attached, the LinkTextBlock attempts to log a message to the debugger.

member.name: T:SolidShineUi.WildcardMatch
member.summary: A class that can match a string against a given target string with wildcards (i.e. "d*g" can match "dig" or "dog" or "ding").

member.name: M:SolidShineUi.WildcardMatch.MatchesWildcard(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Match a string against a given target string with wildcards ("*" and "?" are supported). See Remarks for more details.
member.param: The string to test.
The string to match against, containing the wildcards.
member.returns: True if it can be matched; false if they cannot be.
member.remarks:
This function can match a string against a wildcard string. This is used, for example, in Windows's file dialogs for opening or saving files. Supported wildcard characters are "*", which matches any number of characters, and "?", which matches just one character. (For example, "d*g" will match both "dig" and "ding", where as "d?g" will only match "dig" and not "ding".) Regex (regular expressions) is a lot more powerful than what wildcards alone can provide, but regex strings can also be a lot more complicated to decipher.
This class was written by H.A. Sullivan.

member.name: M:SolidShineUi.WildcardMatch.MatchesWildcard(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Match a string against a given target string with wildcards ("*" and "?" are supported). See Remarks for details.
member.param: The string to test.
The string to match against, containing the wildcards.
Set if letter casing is ignored while matching.
member.returns: True if it can be matched; false if they cannot be.
member.remarks:
This function can match a string against a wildcard string. This is used, for example, in Windows's file dialogs for opening or saving files. Supported wildcard characters are "*", which matches any number of characters, and "?", which matches just one character. (For example, "d*g" will match both "dig" and "ding", where as "d?g" will only match "dig" and not "ding".) Regex (regular expressions) is a lot more powerful than what wildcards alone can provide, but regex strings can also be a lot more complicated to decipher.
This class was written by H.A. Sullivan.
